levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can write and simplify ratios and share a quantity in a given ratio.
levels.example_response: Total parts = 8. Each part = £30. Shares: £90 and £150.
common_errors: Dividing by 3 or 5 instead of 8
Not checking the shares add to £240

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Solves ratio problems including finding one share when another is known, and interprets scale drawings and maps.
levels.example_task: A map scale is 1:25,000. A road is 8 cm on the map. What is the real length in km?
common_errors: Not converting cm to km at the end
Dividing by 25,000 instead of multiplying

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Solves complex ratio problems including combining ratios, using ratio to set up and solve equations, and connecting ratio to fraction/percentage representations.
levels.example_task: In a school, the ratio of boys to girls is 4:5. There are 45 more girls than boys. How many students in total?
levels.example_response: Difference in parts = 5 - 4 = 1 part = 45 students. So 1 part = 45. Total = 9 parts = 9 × 45 = 405 students.
common_errors: Using 45 as the total instead of the difference
Not connecting 'more girls than boys' to the difference in ratio parts

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Solves algebraic ratio problems and problems involving changing ratios.
levels.example_task: Cement, sand and gravel are mixed in the ratio 1:2:3. 15 kg of sand is used. The total is then increased by 50%. Find the new total mass.
levels.example_response: Sand = 2 parts = 15 kg. So 1 part = 7.5 kg. Original total = 6 × 7.5 = 45 kg. Increased by 50%: 45 × 1.5 = 67.5 kg.
common_errors: Confusing which component corresponds to which ratio part
Not applying the 50% increase to the total

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can calculate a percentage of an amount and find percentage increase or decrease.
levels.example_task: A coat costs £80. There is a 15% discount. Find the sale price.
common_errors: Computing 15% but not subtracting from the original
Using 1.15 instead of 0.85 for a decrease

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Uses multipliers for percentage change and solves reverse percentage problems (finding the original value).
levels.example_task: After a 20% increase, a price is £96. Find the original price.
common_errors: Computing 96 - 20% of 96 = £76.80 (wrong — subtracts 20% of the new price)
Not recognising that £96 represents 120%, not 100%

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Solves compound interest problems using the formula A = P(1 + r)ⁿ and compares simple and compound interest.
levels.example_task: £5,000 is invested at 4% compound interest for 3 years. Find the total amount.
common_errors: Using simple interest (5000 + 5000 × 0.04 × 3 = £5,600)
Not raising the multiplier to the power of the number of years

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Solves problems involving repeated proportional change, depreciation and growth models, and evaluates financial products critically.
levels.example_task: A car depreciates by 15% each year. After how many complete years will it be worth less than half its original value?
levels.example_response: After n years: value = P × 0.85ⁿ. Need 0.85ⁿ < 0.5. Taking logs: n > log(0.5)/log(0.85) = -0.301/-0.0706 = 4.27. So after 5 complete years. Check: 0.85⁴ = 0.522 (>0.5), 0.85⁵ = 0.444 (<0.5) ✓.
common_errors: Using 0.85⁴ and concluding 4 years (0.522 > 0.5, so not yet halved)
Not understanding that 'complete years' means rounding up

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Recognises direct proportion (when one quantity doubles, the other doubles) and can solve simple proportion problems using the unitary method.
levels.example_task: 5 pens cost £3.50. How much do 8 pens cost?
common_errors: Using additive reasoning (8-5=3 more, so £3.50 + £3 = £6.50)
Not finding the unit rate

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Writes direct proportion as y = kx and inverse proportion as y = k/x, finding the constant k from given information.
levels.example_task: y is directly proportional to x. When x = 4, y = 20. Find y when x = 7.
levels.example_response: y = kx. 20 = 4k, so k = 5. When x = 7: y = 35.
common_errors: Writing y = x + k (additive) instead of y = kx (multiplicative)
Computing k = y × x instead of k = y/x

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Works with direct and inverse proportion in algebraic, graphical and tabular forms, identifying the type from given data.
levels.example_task: When x is doubled, y is halved. What type of proportion is this? Write the equation if y = 12 when x = 3.
levels.example_response: Inverse proportion: y = k/x. 12 = k/3, k = 36. y = 36/x. Check: when x = 6 (doubled), y = 36/6 = 6 (halved) ✓.
common_errors: Confusing inverse proportion with negative proportion
Computing k = y/x instead of k = xy for inverse proportion

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Works with non-linear proportion (y ∝ x², y ∝ 1/x², y ∝ √x) and solves complex problems in applied contexts. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: The force F between two magnets is inversely proportional to the square of the distance d between them. When d = 2 cm, F = 20 N. Find F when d = 5 cm.
levels.example_response: F = k/d². 20 = k/4, so k = 80. When d = 5: F = 80/25 = 3.2 N. The force drops dramatically with distance — from 20 N to 3.2 N when distance increases from 2 to 5 cm.
common_errors: Using F = k/d instead of F = k/d²
Not squaring the distance

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can use the formula speed = distance/time in straightforward calculations and knows the standard units.
levels.example_task: A car travels 180 km in 3 hours. What is its average speed?
common_errors: Computing 3/180
Forgetting to state the units

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Uses compound units (speed, density, pressure) and can rearrange the formulae to find any variable.
levels.example_task: A block has density 8 g/cm³ and volume 15 cm³. Find its mass.
common_errors: Dividing instead of multiplying
Confusing which formula rearrangement is needed

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Interprets graphs involving compound measures, including distance-time and speed-time graphs, understanding gradient as rate of change.
levels.example_task: On a distance-time graph, the gradient between t = 2 and t = 5 is 40 km/h. What does this represent?
levels.example_response: The gradient represents speed. Between t = 2 and t = 5, the object was travelling at 40 km/h.
common_errors: Not recognising that gradient = speed on a distance-time graph
Confusing distance-time graphs with speed-time graphs

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Interprets area under speed-time graphs as distance, works with non-constant rates of change, and solves complex problems involving multiple compound measures.
levels.example_task: A speed-time graph shows a car accelerating uniformly from 0 to 20 m/s in 10 seconds, then travelling at 20 m/s for 30 seconds. Find the total distance.
levels.example_response: Phase 1 (triangle): distance = ½ × 10 × 20 = 100 m. Phase 2 (rectangle): distance = 30 × 20 = 600 m. Total = 700 m. The area under the speed-time graph equals the distance travelled.
common_errors: Using the speed-time graph as if it were a distance-time graph
Forgetting the ½ for the triangular section
